title: Support Reccomendation for Learning How to Play Safe
body: As the title states, i'm looking for supports that encourage playing a safe lane as i'm starting to recognize that i'm losing a lot because i'm adapting too much of a feast or famine playstyle (Sion support). Besides Janna and Soraka who would you all suggest for a player trying to learn how to play safely so I can learn to climb out of Bronze instead of throwing every game i'm slightly behind.

replies.body: {{champion:43}} She's very versatile and always useful.

>
> {{champion:43}} She's very versatile and always useful.

I'll test her out but from what some people on C9 said in a guide she's not very teamfight oriented aside from a mantra'd ability. Only reason I worry about this is because team fights are really what define a game in bronze/silver i've noticed. Not many people know how to buy a Zz's or a banner (which I guess is a good and bad thing).

I wouldn't take whatever C9 said as very applicable for bronze/silver.  We both know that the teamfight in bronze/silver isn't exactly a coordinated dance.
Karma has this great ability to react and act on many different situations.
I think you'll notice once you have a few games to get to know her that she often shines in those chaotic teamfights.
Her mantra W is an amazing bit for teamfights, but you'll see beyond it.
As a plus, you can waveclear with her, very important (we both know that too ^^")

p.s. nag yourself to try and spam proc her passive whenever you can.
It'll avoid the few awkward starting games that I went through :)

One of my favorite Supports is Thresh because he can play passively and agressively dire the situation. For example, he can Q (hook) in and E (Push) towards you and your adc. On the other hand, he can also sheild and E champions away. He has been a wonder for me, but other good ones are Braum, and Lulu. Youre welcome to add me if you have further questions or need help. TBH the champion you play doesn't have a huge impact on how you 'play safe' as a playstyle, it just changes what safe means. 

For someone like Janna, "safe" can sometimes mean seiging them under their turret if you have wards set up since you have so many peel tools that you'd still be safe even if a gank or roam appeared. Playing "safe" with something weird and janky like vayne support on the other hand would basically mean never leaving under your tower.

Most of the suggestions people have mentioned are good at peeling and making things safe for your adc if they're failing to be safe themselves, but since you mentioned it was you throwing when behind it sounds more like a playstyle issue for you rather than your adc. Remember, playing safe is a playstyle, not a champion pick. Pretty much every champion can be played safely and pretty much everyone can be played aggro as the situation warrants, it's just a matter of having the self-discipline to actually do so.

you are right and wrong. she is a very weird ick because she has tools for both. honestly she works better into poke comps, but her silence can easily stop 2 bursters from doing anyhting, make them miss their combos timing or stop them all together, while her heal keeps her team safe from poke.
what really determines if you should pick her is YOUR team comp.
the harder it will be for the team to get to you, and the more cc you have on your team to peel for you, the better. 
you see, soraka becomes a very high prio target mid game, as this is when people are still low(er) damage, but her heal is already probably redemption empowered. this allows her to literally walk behind someone and heal them through hard focus. the safer sorak will be from the enemy comp the better. you shouldnt usually pick her into assassins/mages who can 100-0 her through her frontline. these are talons and zeds luxs and lbs. unless you are confident in your ability to silence their combo  at a crucial enough point for them to waste cds, but also mitigate most of the damage.

I'd try {{champion:61}}. She's very mana hungry early game, so her laning phase mostly consists of staying back and shielding the adc/using her speed buff to get them out of trouble until she can build some mana items to be useful mid game.

Sona can play safe or aggressive.  Though she probably wins more if she's aggressive.  Karma can play safe and still poke and stuff with her Q, escape with the MS buff on E, and root in W.  Lulu.  Tahm Kench can Devour an aggressive adc to get him tf out.

I really enjoy {{champion:117}} for learning support.  She's squishy and lethal early game which i feel helped/is still helping me learn positioning.  She has incredibly good cc for dives which helped/is helping me learn skill management and understanding what other champions that are diving your adc are capable of.  She's very versatile in that she can be built differently for very different experiences mid/late game which has helped/is helping me learn which items to build for what reasons.  I'm not very good and am still pretty new to the game, but that's my advice as to where to start.  Just try not to tilt and make sure you learn from all the mistakes you're bound to make :)

Nami is very safe. She is a classic enchanter, able to turn bad teamfights around and safely heal/poke during the laning phase.

Lulu is good too. Able to Polymorph the ADC into silence with Whimsy, and can greatly buff the ally with Wild Growth and Help, Pix!

Taric has a very safe lane as well. Bravado keeps your cooldowns low, and the double stun area from Bastion > Dazzle means you can very easily peel if your ADC gets engaged. Cosmic Radiance is a literal lifesaver as well.

If you play Leona but restrict yourself to peel and don't engage, I think that could work. Leona's my #2 champ, so I'm biased.
